Experimental Model and Subject Details Carrizo citrange ( Citrus sinensis ‘Washington’ sweet orange X Poncirus trifoliata ) was used as the experimental model. Carrizo citrange seeds were purchased from Lyn Citrus Seed. W. Murcott mandarin ( Citrus reticulata Blanco) seeds were obtained from USDA ARS, Nat’l Clonal Germplasm Repository for Citrus & Dates. Thornless W. Murcott mandarin was identified as a sport from around 40 seedlings. Cuttings from Citrus aurantiifolia key lime (hereafter referred to as TK), and Citrus aurantiifolia thornless key lime (hereafter referred to as TLK) were kept in an environmentally controlled growth chamber (24°C, 16 h light/8 h dark) at Yale. Plants over one year old were moved to a greenhouse at Marsh Botanical Garden at Yale. For observation of thorn production in Carrizo citrange, seeds were soaked in water overnight and germinated in turface clay, at 24°C under a 16 h day/8 h night regime and grown under these conditions. Emergence of the seedlings occurred within 2 weeks and the plants were then watered three times a week with water and supplemented twice a month with fertilizer (20:10:20) and chelated iron. For decapitation experiments, 20-week old plants with 18 to 25 nodes were decapitated between nodes number 18-20 and growth of the branches was scored 3 weeks later. For DEX treatments, transgenic Carrizo citrange plants with the p35S:CsWUS-GR construct were micro-grafted to Carrizo citrange root stock and well established plants were both sprayed and watered with 20 μM dexamethasone (DEX) or ethanol (0.1%, MOCK) twice a week. Plants were treated for 2 months and phenotypes were documented. Similar treatments were performed for pTI1:CsWUS-GR transgenic plants except that those plants were rooted but not grafted, and treatments lasted 1 month. Method Details Plasmid constructions and plant transformation CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing constructs were produced by using a binary vector expressing hSpCas9 under the Arabidopsis YAO promoter as previously described [ 33 ]. In brief, the primers used to insert the different sgRNAs were synthesized and annealed, and then were ligated to an AtU6-26-sgRNA-SK vector. The AtU6-26 promoter with gRNA was then transferred to the proYAO-Cas9-NOS binary vector. For multiplex genome editing, additional AtU6-26-gRNA cassettes were added to the final vector at the Spe I site. To generate a TI1 -RNAi construct, TI1 CDS was amplified and cloned into a pDONR207 vector then transferred into the binary vector pK7GWIWG2D(II) containing a CaMV 35S promoter (p35S). To generate CsWUS inducible overexpression constructs, CsWUS and GR were fused in-frame by overlapping PCR and cloned into pENTR-D-TOPO vector. The CsWUS -GR fragment was then transferred into the binary vector pK7WG2D to generate the p 35S:CsWUS-GR construct. To place CsWUS - GR under the control of the TI1 promoter, we first mutated the Sac I site within CsWUS CDS without disrupting amino acid coding. The CsWUS CDS and a GR fragment (aa 508-795) was fused together by overlapping PCR and cloned into a pGEMT-easy vector (Promega) with Asc I and Sac I sites. The CsWUS - GR fragment with Asc I and Sac I sites was used to replace the GUS gene of a modified pMDC164 vector, in which the hygromycin phosphotransferase II ( hptII ) selection marker gene was replaced by GFP- neomycin phosphotransferase II ( nptII ) selection marker gene containing a GFP reporter for visual selection. Finally, a TI1 upstream promoter (4144 bp) in pDONR207 vector was transferred into the 164-CsWUS-GR vector to generate the pTI1 : CsWUS-GR construct. The pTI1 : CsWUS construct was generated in a similar manner except that no GR sequence was involved. To construct the pCsWUS:CsWUS , and pCsWUS(mP1):CsWUS , the CsWUS CDS was cloned at the Asc I and Sac I sites of the modified pMDC164 vector as described above. A 1280 bp fragment of the CsWUS promoter was inserted in the sense orientation at the Sac I site. Then a 3212 bp CsWUS upstream promoter with or without mutations in the P1 site was transferred to the pMDC164- CsWUS -3′ by LR reaction to make the pCsWUS(mP1):CsWUS and pCsWUS:CsWUS constructs, respectively. Table S1 contains sequences of oligonucleotides used for cloning. All binary constructs were introduced into Agrobacterium tumefaciens strain EHA105. Carrizo citrange plant transformation was performed as previously described [ 33 , 53 ]. Transgenic plants were selected by kanamycin and the GFP visual marker. Only non-mosaic transgenic plants were rooted and kept for further analysis. Transactivation assay in Carrizo citrange Protoplasts Transient expression constructs were generated as previously described [ 54 ]. In brief, TI1 or TI2 CDS was cloned into the pDONR207 vector, and then transferred to p2GW7 vector for transient overexpression. For eGFP tagged TI1, eGFP was fused in-frame to TI1 by overlapping PCR. For YFP tagged TI2, TI2 CDS from pDONR207 was transferred to pEARLEYGATE 104 vector (containing YFP at the N terminus with a CaMV 35S promoter) by LR reaction to generate the 104-TI2 construct. A pGREEN800II-60LUC vector was constructed as described [ 55 ], except that the 60 base pair minimal 35S fragment was inserted in the Sac II and Nco I sites. A 3212 bp. CsWUS upstream promoter was PCR amplified from Carrizo citrange genomic DNA and cloned into the pGEMT-easy vector. The CsWUS promoter with the mutated TI1 binding sites was generated by Q5 Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (New England Biolabs). The mutated CsWUS promoters were confirmed by sequencing. The CsWUS promoter or its mutated versions were inserted into the SalI and PstI sites in the pGREEN800II-60LUC vector. All reporter and effector constructs were prepared using Plasmid Plus Midi Kit (QIAGEN). Table S1 contains sequences of oligonucleotides used for cloning. Young Carrizo citrange leaves were cut by fresh razor blades and submerged in 0.5 M mannitol solution. The leaves were then transferred to an enzyme solution containing 0.4 M mannitol, 20 mM KCl, 20 mM MES, pH5.7, 0.015 g/mL Cellulose RS, 0.02 g/mL Macerozyme R10, 10 mM CaCl 2 , 0.351 μL/mL 2-Mercaptoethanol, and 0.001 g/mL BSA. Leaves in the enzyme solution were vacuum infiltrated for 10 min and then left on a platform shaker for 16-20 h with gentle mshaking at 50 rpm at room temperature. The protoplast solution was filtered through a mesh with pore size of 150 μm. Protoplasts were then washed, resuspended and transfected exactly as previously described [ 56 ]. Carrizo citrange protoplasts were incubated for 10-14 h in darkness. Detection of luciferase activity was performed by using the Dual-luciferase Reporter Assay System (Promega) on a GLOMAX 20/20 luminometer (Promega). Antibody Generation and purification The full-length TI1 coding sequence was cloned into pMBP-28b vector with the Nco I and Hin d III sites for His-MBP-TI1 fusion protein expression or into pGEX4T-1 vector with Bam H I and SalI sites for GST-TI1 fusion protein expression. All proteins were expressed in BL21 (DE3) E.coli by inducing with 0.5 mM IPTG at 16°C for 16 h. His-MBP-TI1 was purified on amylose resin (New England Biolabs) while GST-TI1 protein was purified on Glutathione Sepharose 4B GST-tagged protein purification resin (GE Healthcare Life Sciences). Purified His-MBP-TI1 protein was injected into two guinea pigs (Cocalico), and the serum was affinity purified using the GST-TI1 protein, as described by Chuck et al. [ 57 ]. Western blot analyses Approximately 20 μg of GW7-TI1-GFP or 104-TI2 construct was used to transfect around 2 × 10 6 Carrizo citrange leaf protoplasts. Protoplasts were harvested and boiled in 30 μL 2 × SDS sample buffer. Proteins were then separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes. Proteins were detected by an anti-GFP antibody (Abcam, ab290). The same blot was stripped and then treated with anti-TI1 antibody. Similar results were obtained from 3 experiments. Chromatin immunoprecipitation ChIP-PCR assays were performed by using affinity purified TI1 antibody as previously described with minor modifications [ 58 ]. Briefly, approximately 1 g of actively growing Carrizo citrange apices was ground in fine powder in liquid nitrogen, and the powder was cross-linked with 1% (v/v) formaldehyde in 30 mL of ChIP extraction buffer 1 (0.4 M sucrose, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 10 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mM DTT, 0.1 mM PMSF, and protease inhibitor cocktail, pH 8.0) for 10 min. 2 mL of 2 M glycine was then added to quench the cross-linking for 5 min. The solution was filtered through layers of Miracloth (EMD Millipore) and then the nuclei were pelleted (3000 g, 20 min at 4°C). The pellet was resuspended in extraction buffer 2 (0.25 M sucrose, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 10 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mM DTT, 0.1 mM PMSF, and protease inhibitor cocktail, pH 8.0). Nuclei and debris were pelleted (12,000 g, 10 min at 4°C). The pellet was resuspended in 500 μL extraction buffer 3 (1.7 M sucrose, 10 mM Tris-HCl, 2 mM MgCl 2 , 0.15% Triton X-100, 1 mM DTT, 0.1 mM PMSF, and protease inhibitor cocktail, pH 8.0) and then overlaid on 600 μL extraction buffer 3 and centrifuged for 1 h at 16,000 g at 4°C. The chromatin pellet was resuspended in 300 μL nuclei lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, 10 mM EDTA and 1% SDS, pH 8.0). Chromatin was sonicated in a Bioruptor (Diagenode) for 20 min (30 s on, 30 s off, high level) to yield DNA fragments of 0.3-1.0 kb in length. The sonicated suspension was centrifuged at 12000 g for 5 min at 4°C. 10 μL of the supernatant was kept to serve as input. 3 mL of ChIP dilution buffer (16.7 mM Tris-HCl, 1.2 mM EDTA, 167 mM NaCl, and 1.1% Triton X-100, pH 8.0) was added to the supernatant. The chromatin sample was precleared with Dynabeads protein A and then incubated with either TI1 antibody or non-immune serum overnight at 4°C. The immune complexes were collected with Dynabeads protein A for 1 h at 4°C and then washed by low salt wash buffer, high salt wash buffer, LiCl wash buffer and TE buffer. The immune complexes were eluted by 100 μL elution buffer (1% SDS, 0.1M NaHCO3) at 65°C for 30 min, followed by reverse crosslinking, RNase A treatment and proteinase K treatment. DNA was purified by ChIP DNA Clean & Concentrator kit (Zymo Research). Purified DNA was subjected to qPCR analysis using primers listed at Table S1 . The final relative enrichment fold changes were calculated by normalizing % input of each primer pair against the control gene (beta- tubulin ). In Carrizo citrange leaf protoplasts, ChIP assays were performed as described previously [ 54 , 59 ]. Approximately 50 μg of the p35S:TI1-eGFP construct was transformed into 2 × 10 7 Carrizo citrange leaf protoplasts, which were incubated at room temperature for 10 h. Protoplasts were collected and resuspended with W5 medium with 1% formaldehyde for cross-linking at room temperature for 20 min, and then were quenched with 0.2 M glycine for 5 min. Nuclei were extracted in extraction buffer 1 as described above and lysed in 300 μL nuclei lysis buffer. The rest of the ChIP steps were carried exactly as described above except that anti-GFP (Abcam, ab290) or anti-HA (Sigma, H6908) antibodies were used for the immunoprecipitation. Each experiment was repeated three times and similar results were obtained. Histology Plant material was manually dissected and fixed in 10% formaldehyde, 5% acetic acid, 50% ethanol (FAA), for 1 h under vacuum and on ice. Fresh FAA was added to the samples and incubated overnight at 4°C with rotation. Samples were dehydrated in an ethanol series before critical point drying; samples were then sputter coated with gold and images were captured on a Zeiss ISI-SS40 scanning electron microscope equipped with digital image capture. Detection of lignin was carried out on 8 micron sections that had been dewaxed, rehydrated and stained with phloroglucinol-HCl (1 volume of 2% (w/v) phloroglucinol in 95% ethanol with 1 volume of concentrated HCl) and mounted under a coverslip. Stained material was photographed within 30 min of staining. RNA-seq Young shoot tips (approximately 5 mm long) were collected from actively flushing branches of trees (thorned or thornless key lime). For each variety, three samples corresponding to a pool of three young shoots were used for RNA extraction. RNA was then extracted using TRizol reagent (Life Technology, USA) and was further cleaned using DNase I and RNeasy Mini Kit (QIAGEN, USA). The mRNA was enriched through mRNA purification kit (Dynabeads mRNA purification kit, Invitrogen) or rRNA depletion kit (Ribo-Zero rRNA Removal Kit, Plant Leaf, Epicenter) following the manufacturer’s recommendation. Quality of the purified mRNA and total RNA (rRNA depleted) was verified on a Bioanalyzer using the RNA Pico assay and RNA concentration was determined in parallel using a low range Quant-iT RiboGreen RNA assay kit (Life Technology, USA). Paired end, directional libraries were prepared with the ScriptSeq v2 RNA-Seq Library Preparation Kit (Epicenter) by using 5ng of RNA (polyA enriched or rRNA-depleted). Individual barcodes were added to each sample. PCR products ranging in size between 250-500bp were purified using AMPure system Agencourt (Beckman Coulter) and quality of the products was assessed on the Agilent Bioanalyzer using the High Sensitivity DNA assay. The 12 individually barcoded libraries were pooled, loaded in one lane of the flow cell of a HiSeq2000 sequencer (Illumina, USA) and run at the J. Craig Venter Institute (JCVI, USA). Raw reads were filtered using fastq-m cf [ 60 ]. Reads with quality score above 20 were kept. Cleaned reads of each cultivar were pooled and used for de novo transcriptome assembly with the Trinity program [ 61 ] and CLC Workbench Genomics to generate transcripts. Reference database for quality assessment were made from Citrus transcriptomes/ genomes publicly available ( https://www.citrusgenomedb.org ). The open reading frames were predicted and translated in proteins with the TransDecoder utility ( https://github.com/TransDecoder/TransDecoder/releases ). Raw reads from each of the libraries were mapped against the Trinity reconstructed transcripts in CLC with the following parameters: at least 80% identity over 50% of the read. The alignment was subsequently used for RSEM [ 62 ] analysis to estimate transcript abundance. In order to reduce the redundancy of assemblies, each of the species proteome was de-duplicated using USEARCH [ 63 ]. USEARCH clustering was then performed re-iteratively at 100%, 97%, 95%, 90% and 50% identity. The clustering was done by starting with the most stringent criteria, then using the centroids (longest) sequence of the clusters as the sequences to cluster at the next level. Different types of cluster classes were defined to illustrate the possible combinations of orthologs, isoforms and paralogs across the 5 species and the percentage identity at which the orthologs clustered. In addition, orthoMCL [ 64 ] clustering was performed with filters set at 50% identity and 80% and 95% length. The clustering method uses reciprocal best blast hits to generate the clusters. Analyses of differential expression including FDR calculations were performed using the Bioconductor package edgeR [ 65 ]. Each condition was compared in a pairwise fashion. Peptide annotations were transferred by BLAST. First, peptides were submitted to a first BLASTX analysis against the TAIR10 proteins database. The remaining peptides with no Arabidopsis hits were then used for a BLASTX analysis against UniPROT filtered for plant proteins and with Arabidopsis proteins removed. GO annotation of the matching Arabidopsis peptides were retrieved using ThaleMine ( https://apps.araport.org/thalemine/bag.do ). Lists of transcription factors used for analyses were retrieved from the PlantTFdb web site ( http://planttfdb.cbi.pku.edu.cn/ ). Expression analysis Total RNA was extracted from samples of tissues using a Direct-zol RNA MiniPrep kit (ZYMO Research) with DNase I treatment to remove any contaminating DNA. One microgram of RNA from each sample was used to generate cDNA using an iScript cDNA synthesis kit (BioRad). qPCR analyses were carried out with a CFX96 Real-Time PCR Detection System (BioRad) using iQ SYBR Green supermix (BioRad). Actin was used as a reference gene and relative expression values were calculated using the 2 -ΔΔCt method. Fold change and standard error was calculated from three biological replicates. In situ hybridization Plant apices were fixed and dehydrated as described above. CsSTM , CsWUS , TI1 , TI2 and HISTONEH4 fragments were amplified from Carrizo citrange cDNA from Carrizo citrange shoot tips, using primers listed in Table S1 , and sub-cloned into the pGEMT-easy vector following the manufacturer’s recommendations (Promega). Antisense probes were synthesized from the SP6 promoter using Roche reagent and hydrolyzed to 120 bp long fragments. In situ hybridizations were performed essentially as previously described [ 66 ]. Electrophoresis mobility gel shift assay (EMSA) The fragments of CsWUS promoter labeled with 3′ biotin were synthesized by the Keck facility at Yale University. Unlabeled oligos were used for the competition assays. Purified MBP or His-MBP-TI1 were used in the EMSA. EMSA was performed as described previously [ 67 ]. Phylogenetic analysis Phylogenetic relationships were inferred using the Neighbor-Joining method implemented on MEGA7 after alignment using MUSCLE [ 68 ]. A complete list of sequences used to generate the CYC / BRC1 phylogeny is available in Table S3 . Quantification and Statistical Analysis For thorn frequency analysis ( Figure S1 A), 84 independent plants were assayed. For branch meristem outgrowth analysis ( Figure S1 B), 12 non-decapitated and 19 decapitated plants were assayed. For gene expression analysis by qRT-PCR (as shown in Figures 3 D, 3S, and 6 B), three replicates were assayed. For transient assays in leaf protoplasts (as shown in Figures 6 D and 6F), at least three independent biological experiments were performed. For ChIP-qPCR analysis (as shown in Figures 6 G and S5 B), at least three independent biological experiments were performed. Statistical analysis was performed through Student’s t test in Excel.
